8   Appendix 3 
 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  necessary  to  (i)  develop 
feasibility study of the Kundaliya Irrigation Project (KIP), (ii) review the technical and economic 
viability  of  KIP,  (iii)  evaluate  and  address  safeguard  requirements,  (iv)  prepare  project  1 
consultants  request  for  proposal  and  KIP’s  tender  and  turnkey  contract  documents, 
(v) undertake financial and procurement assessments of the executing agency, (vi) prepare all 
requirements  for  a  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  and  project,  and  (vii)  support 
implementation start-up. 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  Key outputs of the PPTA are listed in Table A3.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $1,050,000 equivalent, of which $1,000,000 equivalent 
will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). 
The  use  of  TASF  is  required  to  expedite  loan  processing  and  meet  the  government’s 
development schedule. The government has been advised that approval of the PPTA does not 
commit  ADB  to  financing  any  ensuing  investment  program.  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and housing accommodation, office 
supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic  transportation,  provision  of  office  space, 
communication facilities for consultants, surveys, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed 
cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The PPTA will be implemented from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. A total of 54 
person-months  of consulting  services  will  be  provided,  of  which  25 person-months  will  be 
individually recruited international consultants and 29 person-months of national consultants will 
be recruited through a firm. It is proposed to recruit WAPCOS INDIA as the national consultants 
through  single  source  selection  since  it  is  already  contracted  by  the  Water  Resources 
Department Madhya Pradesh (MPWRD) for undertaking advanced project preparation studies. 
These will be updated under the PPTA and therefore the selection of WAPCOS will provide 
natural continuation in preparing the investment program. Consultant requirements are shown in 
Table A3.3. 
5.  The specialists will be engaged to undertake the PPTA to (i) assist MPWRD to prepare 
feasibility  designs,  cost  estimates  and  procurement  documents;  (ii)  undertake  surveys  and 
prepare environment and resettlement safeguard documents; (iii) prepare necessary Board 
documents; and (iv) support MPWRD with supervising detailed design review and approval. The 
outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 6 to 19.

6.  Team Leader, Water Resources and Irrigation Planning Specialist (international, 7 
person-months) will (i) manage the PPTA teams and ensure quality control of PPTA outputs; 
(ii) prepare all PPTA outputs, and MFF and loan documents; (iii) assess the water balances of

10  Appendix 3 
the  Kundaliya  Major  Multipurpose  Project  and  Sanjay  Sarovar  Irrigation  Project  (SSIP) 
considering  future  water  availability  and  demands  taking  into  account  cropping  patterns, 
development plans,1 other users, and climate change; (iv) recommend monitoring and control 
systems; and (v) assist MPWRD with evaluating bid submissions for the implementation turnkey 
contract, and reviewing  detailed designs. 
7.  Pipeline Design Specialist (international, 4 person-months) will (i) model and optimize 
KIP’s pump and pipe network to minimize capital and operation costs while ensuring optimum 
water delivery service; (ii) prepare feasibility designs, specifications and cost estimates; and 
(iii) assist MPWRD with evaluating bid submissions for the implementation turnkey contract, and 
reviewing detailed designs. 
8.  Pumps  Specialist  (international,  3  person-months)  will  (i)  develop  KIP’s  layout  of 
pumping  stations  and pressurized  pipe  network  and  preparing feasibility  designs  and  cost 
estimates; (ii) advise on options for optimizing energy usage and maximizing savings in the 
design and operation of KIP; and (iii) assist MPWRD in evaluating bid submissions for the 
implementation turnkey contract, and reviewing the contractor’s detailed designs. 
9.  Project Economist and Financial Management Specialists (international, 4 person-
months and national 2 person-months) will (i) undertake an economic analysis in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects (1997), (ii) identify the economic 
risks associated with the investment program and undertaking a sensitivity and risk analysis, 
(iii) undertake financial sustainability analysis of KIP; (iv) prepare the costing of the investment 
program and project 1, and (v) undertake a financial management assessment of MPWRD.  
10.  Procurement  Specialist  (international,  3  person-months)  will  (i)  undertake  a 
procurement  assessment  of  MPWRD;  (ii) assess  the  procurement  risk  and  facilitating 
appropriate processes to mitigate those risks; (iii) prepare the project 1 procurement plan; 
(iv) advise on procurement methods for project 1 works; (v) prepare master bidding documents; 
and (vi) assist with contracting actions, and supporting MPWRD with evaluating bid documents. 
11.  Irrigation Institutions Specialist (international, 4 person-months) will (i) establish the 
institutional and legal context of this investment program and its linkages with other national 
initiatives;  (ii) review  the  sector’s  legislative framework  and  institutional  arrangements,  and 
recommends improvements, if any; (iii) undertake a sector assessment of Madhya Pradesh’s 
water resources and irrigated agriculture sector; (iv) develop an extension program to support 
the transition to micro-irrigation, and assess the requirements for training and awareness; and 
(v)  develop  an  institutional  framework  for  performance  based  management,  operation  and 
maintenance of KIP. 
12.  Agricultural  Specialist  (national,  4  person-months)  will  (i)  assess  current  cropping 
systems and farming strategies in KIP and SSIP, (ii) recommend improvements of on-field water 
management and crop production, and (iii) assess crop water requirements. 
13.  Environmental Safeguards Specialist (national, 3 person-months) will (i) prepare an 
environmental assessment and review framework for the investment program in accordance to 
government and ADB requirements as describe in ADB’s Safeguards Policy Statement (2009) 
(SPS), (ii) undertake a rapid environmental assessment for the investment program to confirm 
the environmental safeguard categorization, and (iii) prepare environmental assessment study 
for project 1. Together with the resettlement specialist, the environment safeguards specialist 
will  also  undertake  an  assessment  of  safeguard  requirements  and  implementation  for

associated facilities, and determine any risk that could affect the successful operation of KIP, 
and identify potential remedial actions. 
14.  Resettlement Specialist (national, 3 person-months) will (i) prepare social safeguards 
frameworks for indigenous people and for involuntary resettlement for the investment program, 
and a resettlement plan for project 1, all in accordance with government regulations and SPS; 
(ii)  undertake  a  100%  census  of  the  affected  people  to  identify  the  scope  of  involuntary 
resettlement impacts, identify type and detail losses, and identify any impacts to indigenous 
people as describe in SPS; and (iii) conduct consultations with potential affected people to 
ensure they are aware of the project’s potential impacts on their livelihoods. 
15.  Social Development Specialist (national, 3 person-months) will (i) carry out a poverty 
and social impacts assessment; (ii) prepare a poverty and social analysis report in accordance 
to ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis (2012); (iii) confirm the gender classification 
for project 1 and if required prepare a gender action plan; and (iv) prepare a summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy for the investment program. 
16.  Participatory  Irrigation  Specialist  (national,  4  person-months)  will  (i)  liaise  with 
farmers and water user groups, (ii) obtain feedback from farmers on transitioning to micro-
irrigation, and (iii) develop an extension support plan to foster rapid uptake of micro-irrigation. 
17.  Geographic Information System Specialist (national, 4 person-months) will (i) source 
and develop a digital elevation map of the KIP gross command area; (ii) develop cadastral, 
land-use and soil layers for the geographic information system database; and (iii) assist PPTA 
team members for planning layout of KIP system. 
18.  Electric Power Specialist (national, 3 person-months) will (i) assess the impact of KIP 
on existing power availability; (ii) review existing power transmission systems and advising on 
required new infrastructure; (iii) prepare feasibility designs for power infrastructure (including a 
new solar farm), cost estimates, and specifications; (iv) advise on options for optimizing energy 
usage;  (v) recommend  climate  change  mitigation  initiatives;  and  (vi)  assist  MPWRD  in 
evaluating bid submissions for turnkey contract, and reviewing the contractor’s detail designs. 
19.  Hydrologist (national, 3 person-months) will (i) undertake hydrological analyses for both 
KIP and SSIP including an assessment of climate change; and (ii) assess the surface and 
groundwater water availability. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  MPWRD will be the executing agency for the PPTA. Consultants will be mobilized in a 
staggered manner with a focus on prioritizing the advance actions on (i) undertaking requisite 
surveys and investigations, and due diligence on technical and economic matters; (ii) supporting 
civil  works  contract  procurement;  and  (iii)  recruiting  the  program  management  and  design 
consultant.  Disbursement  under  the  PPTA  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). The proposed 
PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4. 
Table A3.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Major Milestones  Expected Completion Date 
Concept paper clearance (including PPTA)  December 2015 
Consultant mobilization  January 2016 
Completion of PPTA  December 2017 
PPTA = project preparatory technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.
